brief_summary.textblock:
The investigators hypothesize that the physiological effects of milk on satiety and glycemic
      control are mediated by the interaction between its macronutrient components by both
      insulin-dependent and independent mechanisms.

clinical_study.brief_title: Mechanism of Action of Milk and Its Components on Glycemic Control in Healthy Young Men

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Healthy young men

          -  20-30 years of age

          -  BMI:  20-24.9 kg/m2

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Smoking

          -  Dieting

          -  Skipping breakfast

          -  Lactose intolerance or allergies to milk

          -  Taking medications that may affect glucose metabolism or appetite

          -  Diabetes (fasting blood glucose ≥ 7.0 mmol/L) or other metabolic diseases

intervention.description: Commercially available milk from the grocery store
Added lactose + fat + protein together to form a mixture

other_outcome.description:
Gatrointestinal hormones measured include plasma concentrations of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1), peptide tyrosine tyrosine (PYY), cholecystokinin (CCK), and ghrelin.
Gastric emptying is assessed indirectly by adding 1.5 g of paracetamol (acetaminophen) to each beverage and measuring plasma paracetamol concentrations.
other_outcome.measure: Gastrointestinal hormones and gastric emptying rate

oversight_info.authority: Canada:  University of Toronto Research Ethics Board

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Primary Purpose: Prevention
